b.  Certify the assessment amount to the county treasurer for collection in the same manner as taxes are authorized to be, pursuant to the provisions of C.R.S. § 31-20-105. 
(7)  Any protesting owner dissatisfied with the decision of city council shall have the right to have the decision reviewed pursuant to Rule 106 of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure, provided that such a review is sought within the time and in the manner provided by law. 
(8)  Immediately upon its being placed on the assessment roll, the assessment shall be deemed to be complete, the several amounts assessed shall be payable, and the assessments shall be liens against the lots or parcels of land assessed, respectively. The lien shall continue until the assessment and all interest due and payable thereon are paid. 
(9)  All such assessments remaining unpaid after thirty (30) days from the date of recording on the assessment roll shall become delinquent and shall bear interest at the rate of ten (10) percent per annum from and after said date. 
(10)  After confirmation of the assessment notice, certified copies of the assessment shall be given to the assessor and the treasurer for the county, who shall add the amount of the assessment to the next regular tax bill levied against the parcel for city purposes. 
(11)  The amount of the assessment shall be collected at the same time and in the same manner as ordinary property taxes are collected and shall be subject to the same penalties and procedure and sale in case of delinquency as provided for ordinary property taxes. All laws applicable to the levy, collection and enforcement of property taxes shall be applicable to such assessment. 
(12)  All money recovered by payment of the charge or assessment or from the sale of the property at foreclosure sale shall be paid to the director of finance for the City of Alamosa, who shall credit the same to the City of Alamosa Graffiti Removal Account. 
(g)  Alternative remedies. It is the intent of the city council that the provisions and procedures set forth in this section shall not expressly or by implication repeal or supersede any other provisions or procedures under city ordinance, state law, or otherwise. This section shall supplement existing procedures and will provide an alternative, nonexclusive procedure for the abatement of graffiti nuisances. Nothing in this section shall preclude abatement of graffiti by the City of Alamosa through civil process by means of preliminary or permanent injunction or in any other manner provided by law for the abatement of such nuisance. Nothing in this section shall preclude or prohibit the City of Alamosa from resorting to any appropriate legal remedy, whether civil or criminal, in the abatement of any graffiti, and when such other remedy is utilized, the hearing and appeal procedures provided in this section to determine the existence of a nuisance shall not be applicable. 
(h)  Public property. Where property is owned by a public entity other than the City of Alamosa, the assessment of costs provisions contained in this section shall not apply. All other provisions of this section shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 1-2008, § 1, 2-6-08; Ord. No. 13-2017 , § 2, 6-7-17; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § G13, 10-3-18) 
Editor's note— Former § 11-107. See Editor's Note in § 11-104.  
Secs. 11-106—11-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES RELATING TO WEAPONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 8, 2011, § 1, adopted July 6, 2011, amended the former Art. VII, §§ 11-117—11-121, and enacted a new Art. VII as set out herein. The former Art. VII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1964, §§ 17-66, 17-67; Ord. No. 21-1999, §§ 13, 14, adopted Nov. 17, 1999; Ord. No. 1-2009, § 1, adopted Jan. 21, 2009. 
State Law reference— Offenses relating to weapons, C.R.S. 18-12-101 et seq.; discharge of firearm in public place prohibited, C.R.S. 18-9-106(e); carrying a concealed weapon, C.R.S. 18-12-105, 18-12-201 et seq. 
 
Sec. 11-116. - Definition of "deadly weapon." 
As used in this article VII, "deadly weapon" means any of the following which in the manner it is used or intended to be used is capable of producing death or serious bodily injury: 
(1)  A firearm, whether loaded or unloaded; 
(2)  A knife; 
(3)  A bludgeon; or 
(4)  Any other weapon, device, instrument, material, or substance, whether animate or inanimate. 
(Ord. No. 8, 2011, § 1, 7-6-11)  
Sec. 11-117. - Carrying concealed weapons. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than a law enforcement officer in the performance of his or her duty, or any person having a permit to carry a concealed handgun issued pursuant to the provisions of C.R.S. 18-12-210 et seq., to be found carrying concealed upon his or her person any pistol, bowie knife, dagger or other deadly weapon or any stars, num-chucks or other martial arts weapons unless going directly to or from a sanctioned meet or training session. 
(Ord. No. 8, 2011, § 1, 7-6-11; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § G14, 10-3-18) 
State Law reference— Carrying a concealed weapon, C.R.S. 18-12-105; Permits for concealed weapons, C.R.S. 18-12-201 et seq.  
Sec. 11-118. - Carrying weapons with intent to assault. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have upon him or her any gun, pistol, knife, dirk, bludgeon or other deadly weapon, with intent to assault any person. 
(Ord. No. 8, 2011, § 1, 7-6-11; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § G15, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 11-119. - Firearms, BB guns, air guns, gas operated guns, spring guns, etc.; use prohibited 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a law enforcement officer in the performance of his or her duty, to discharge or use any firearm, air gun, BB gun, gas operated gun, spring gun, or similar type of gun in the city except as exempted below. 
(b)  The following shall not constitute a violation of this article: 
(1)  The discharge of a firearm in defense of person in accordance with C.R.S. 18-1-704 or against an intruder in accordance with C.R.S. 18-1-704.5; 
(2)  The discharge of a firearm for the legitimate sporting use of such weapons within areas specifically designed and lawfully permitted by the City of Alamosa for the discharge or weapons such as shooting ranges, rifle ranges, and shooting galleries; 
(3)  The discharge of a firearm during a legitimate organized educational class or course under adult instruction and supervision within areas specifically designed for the discharge of such weapons; 
(4)  The discharge of a firearm by representatives of service, fraternal, athletic or educational organizations/institutions firing blank cartridges at training sessions, ceremonial occasions of the nature of funeral rights, parades, starting guns at formal athletic meets, or rehearsals for such occasions and similar events; 
(5)  The discharge of a firearm within a structure as part of a legitimate research, testing, or scientific process or investigation; or 
(6)  The discharge of a firearm within the confines of the city's active cattle ranch for predator and wildlife control if authorized in writing by the city manager and chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 8, 2011, § 1, 7-6-11) 
State Law reference— Use of deadly physical force, C.R.S. 18-1-701 et seq.  
Sec. 11-120. - Deadly weapons, liquor establishments. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, without legal authority, to carry, conceal or display a deadly weapon on the premises of any establishment where malt, vinous or spirituous liquors are sold for consumption on the premises. This section shall not prohibit the display, sale or auction, in an establishment where malt, vinous or spirituous liquors are sold, of unloaded firearms, with trigger locks or other disabling safety mechanism acceptable to the chief of police or the chief's designee, by any not-for-profit organization, where the weapon is not delivered to any purchaser until after the event has terminated, pursuant to special event permit to be issued by the chief of police, or the chief's designee, conditioned upon such security arrangements as the chief, in the exercise of reasonable discretion, deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 8, 2011, § 1, 7-6-11; Ord. No. 1-2019 , § 1, 1-16-19)  
Sec. 11-121. - Confiscation and disposition of deadly weapons. 
(a)  After conviction of a defendant, the court may order the forfeiture of any firearms, deadly weapons and illegal weapons which were used by the defendant during the course of the episode which gave rise to said conviction as an element of sentencing or as condition of probation or of a deferred sentence. 
(b)  Firearms and weapons forfeited under this section, as well as illegal weapons, shall be disposed of by the chief of police, or the chief's designee, as ordered by the court. 
(Ord. No. 8, 2011, § 1, 7-6-11; Ord. No. 1-2018 , § 6, 2-7-18; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § G16, 10-3-18)  
Secs. 11-122—11-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES RELATING TO MINORS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Children prohibited from taverns; exceptions, § 10-26; purchases by minors from secondhand dealers prohibited, § 10-166; curfew for minors, § 11-1. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 11-131—11-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OBTAINING, USE, POSSESSION OR PURCHASE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS BY MINORS 
 
Sec. 11-151. - Definitions. 
As used in sections 11-151 through 11-157 of this division, the following words and phrases are defined as follows: 
Minor means any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
Smoking means the holding or carrying of a lighted pipe, lighted cigar, or lighted cigarette of any kind, and includes the lighting of a pipe, cigar, or cigarette of any kind. 
Tobacco product means any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipes, tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco, or dipping tobacco. It shall be rebuttably presumed that a substance within a package or container is a tobacco product if the package or container has affixed to it a label which identifies the package or container as containing a tobacco product. 
(Ord. No. 3-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 3A-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 12-1998, § 1, 6-17-98)  
Sec. 11-152. - Unlawful possession of tobacco products by minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to possess any tobacco product within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to consume or use, either by smoking, ingesting, absorbing, or chewing, any tobacco product within the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to purchase, obtain, or attempt to purchase or obtain any tobacco product within the city. 
(Ord. No. 3-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 3A-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 12-1998, § 1, 6-17-98)  
Sec. 11-153. - Unlawful furnishing of tobacco products to minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly furnish to any minor, by gift, sale, or any other means, any tobacco product. 
(b)  It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under this section that the person furnishing the tobacco product is presented with a reasonable and relied upon document which identified the minor receiving the tobacco product as being eighteen (18) years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. 3-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 3A-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 12-1998, § 1, 6-17-98)  
Sec. 11-154. - Vending machines. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer to sell cigarettes or tobacco products by use of vending machine or other coin-operated machine; except that cigarettes may be sold through a vending machine in which only tobacco products are sold, and only through such machines in: 
(1)  Factories, businesses, offices, or other places not opened to the general public; 
(2)  Places to which minors are not permitted access; or 
(3)  Places open to the general public and to which minors are permitted access only where the vending machine is under the direct supervision of the owner of the establishment or an adult employee of the owner. 
(b)  As used in this section, "under direct supervision" means that the vending machine shall be in plain vision of the owner or adult employee during regular business hours. 
(c)  In places where the vending machine is under the direct supervision of the owner of the establishment or an adult employee of the owner, and a minor uses the vending machine to obtain tobacco products, the owner of the establishment and/or the adult employee of the owner under whom the vending machine is under direct supervision shall be presumed to have knowingly furnished and sold a tobacco product to a minor. 
(d)  It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under this section that the person selling or offering to sell the tobacco products was presented with and reasonably relied upon a document which identified the person purchasing the tobacco product as being eighteen (18) years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. 3-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 3A-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 12-1998, § 1, 6-17-98)  
Sec. 11-155. - Sale of tobacco products. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any business proprietor, manager, or other person in charge or in control of a business of any kind to engage, employ, or permit any minor to sell tobacco products for such business. 
(b)  As of June 1, 1998, it shall be unlawful for any business proprietor, manager, or other person in charge or control of a business of any kind to stock or display a tobacco product in any way which allows a customer access to such tobacco product without first securing the physical assistance of an adult business employee for each transaction. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a minor to enter a place of business or store engaged primarily in the sale of tobacco products when the minor is not accompanied by his or her parent or guardian. Entry of a minor into a business establishment or shop engaged primarily in the sale of tobacco products shall result in a violation of this section by the minor and the owner of the business establishment or store and/or the adult employee on duty at the business establishment or store. 
(Ord. No. 3-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 3A-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 12-1998, § 1, 6-17-98)  
Sec. 11-156. - Motor vehicle enforcement. 
No driver or passenger in a motor vehicle shall be cited for a violation of sections 11-152 through 11-155 of this division unless the driver of said motor vehicle was stopped by a law enforcement officer for an alleged violation of another ordinance in the Code of Ordinances of Alamosa, Colorado, or the Colorado Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 3-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 3A-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 12-1998, § 1, 6-17-98)  
Sec. 11-157. - Penalties. 
Minimum penalties for violation of sections 11-152 through 11-155 of this division by a minor shall be as follows: 
(1)  A monetary fine, community service, and/or participation in a tobacco education program. 
(2)  Upon a second violation of sections 11-152 through 11-155 by a minor, the parent(s) or guardian(s) may be penalized. 
(Ord. No. 3-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 3A-1998, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 12-1998, § 1, 6-17-98; Ord. No. 11-2001, § 8, 12-19-01)  
Sec. 11-158. - Purchase of cigarettes and tobacco products by minors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to purchase any cigarettes or tobacco products. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "tobacco products" shall mean cigars, cheroots, stogies, periques, granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed, and other smoking tobacco, snuff, snuff flour, cavendish, plug and twist tobacco, fine-cut and other chewing tobaccos, shorts, refuse scraps, clippings, cuttings and sweepings of tobacco, and other kinds and forms of tobacco, prepared in such manner as to be suitable for chewing or for smoking in a pipe or otherwise, or both for chewing and smoking, but does not include cigarettes. 
(Ord. No. 27-1998, § 3, 12-16-98)  
Secs. 11-159—11-170. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PURCHASE OR POSSESSION OF CERTAIN SUBSTANCES BY MINORS 
 
Sec. 11-171. - Illegal possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol or marijuana by an underage person. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to possess or consume any substance which is or contains ethyl alcohol. 
(1)  Possession of an ethyl alcohol substance means that a person has or holds any amount of ethyl alcohol in any form anywhere on his or her person, or that a person owns or has custody of ethyl alcohol, or has ethyl alcohol within his or her immediate possession or control. Illegal possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol by an underage person is a strict liability offense. 
(b)  Except as described by Section 14 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution and C.R.S. § 18-18-406.3, a person under twenty-one (21) years of age who possesses marijuana or consumes marijuana anywhere in the State of Colorado commits illegal possession or consumption of marijuana by an underage person. "Possession of marijuana" means that a person has or holds any amount of marijuana anywhere on his or her person or that a person owns or has custody of marijuana or has marijuana within his or her immediate presence and control. Illegal possession or consumption of marijuana by an underage person is a strict liability offense. 
(c)  Prima facie evidence of a violation of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall consist of: 
(1)  Evidence that the defendant was under the age of twenty-one (21) years and possessed or consumed ethyl alcohol or marijuana anywhere in the city; or 
(2)  Evidence that the defendant was under the age of twenty-one (21) years and manifested any of the characteristics commonly associated with ethyl alcohol intoxication or impairment or marijuana impairment anywhere in the city. 
(d)  The evidentiary provisions and affirmative defenses set forth in C.R.S. §§ 18-13-122 shall apply in all proceedings regarding a violation of subsections (a) and (b), above, and are incorporated herein by reference. 
(e)  Possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol or marijuana shall not constitute a violation of this section if such possession or consumption takes place for religious purposes protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. 
(f)  An underage person shall be immune from prosecution under this section if he or she establishes the following: 
(1)  The underage person called 911 and reported in good faith that another underage person was in need of medical assistance due to alcohol or marijuana consumption; 
(2)  The underage person who called 911 provided his or her name to the 911 operator; 
(3)  The underage person was the first person to make the 911 report; and 
(4)  The underage person who made the 911 call remained on the scene with the underage person in need of medical assistance until assistance arrived and cooperated with medical assistance or law enforcement personnel on the scene. 
(g)  The court, upon sentencing a defendant pursuant to this section may, in addition to any fine, order the defendant to perform up to twenty-four (24) hours of useful public service, and may further order the defendant to submit to and complete an alcohol or evaluation or assessment, an alcohol or drug education program, or an alcohol or drug treatment program at the defendant's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2-2017 , § 5, 2-15-17; Ord. No. 1-2018 , § 7, 2-7-18; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § G13, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 11-172. - Unlawful for underage person to obtain or attempt to obtain alcoholic beverages or marijuana by misrepresentation of age or other method. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain or attempt to obtain any alcohol beverage or marijuana or marijuana product by misrepresentation of age or by any other method in any place where alcohol beverages or marijuana produce are sold when such person is under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2-2017 , § 6, 2-15-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2-2017 , § 6, adopted February 15, 2017, repealed former § 11-172, and subsequently renumbered former § 11-173 as § 11-172. Former § 11-172 pertained to offenses relating to marijuana and marijuana concentrate and derived from Ord. No. 27-1998, adopted December 16, 1998. See § 11-11 for provisions relating to offenses relating to marijuana.  
Chapter 12 - MOBILE HOMES, MOBILE HOME PARKS AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, adopted May 2, 2018, repealed the former ch. 12, §§ 12-1 and 12-16—12-41, and reenacted a new ch. 12 to read as set out herein. Former ch. 12 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1964, §§ 19-4(2), 19-4(3), 19-46(5)—19-4(12), 19-4(14)—19-4(22), 19-4(24)—19-4(26). 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 4; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; flood damage prevention, Ch. 8; specific standards for flood hazard reduction, § 8-52; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 10; nuisances, Ch. 14; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 16; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19; utilities, Ch. 20; uniform development code, Ch. 21. 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Manufactured home means a structure transportable in one (1) or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and is designed for use with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and which has certification required by the United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and was constructed is in compliance with the requirements of 42 U.S.C. § 5401, et seq., Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards, and the regulations of the Department of Housing and Urban Development that are promulgated thereunder. The phrase "manufactured home" does not include a recreational vehicle, nor does it include a mobile home. 1 
Manufactured home park or subdivision means a parcel of land that is divided (or, in the case of the subdivision, platted) into two (2) or more lots for long-term lease or sale, with infrastructure designed for the installation of manufactured homes. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18) 
1 The phrase "mobile home" typically refers to a structure similar to a manufactured home, but built before 1976, and not built to HUD standards which became effective in 1976. Unless grandfathered in in an existing mobile home park, mobile homes are not allowed in the City of Alamosa.  
Secs. 12-2—12-15. - Reserved.  
Sec. 12-16. - Location outside park or subdivision prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or occupy a manufactured home for human habitation within the city limits except in a licensed manufactured home park or a manufactured home subdivision, provided that this prohibition shall not include a manufactured home used for an office for temporary use while construction is in progress at such location. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-17. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate within the limits of the city any manufactured home park, without first obtaining a license. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-18. - Application for license. 
Application for a manufactured home park license shall be filed with the city clerk and issued by the city council upon approval of the application by the city manager. Applications shall be in duplicate in writing, signed by the applicant and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The location and legal description of the manufactured home park; 
(3)  A complete plan of the park showing compliance with section 21-4-805; 
(4)  Plans and specifications of all buildings and other improvements constructed or to be constructed in the manufactured home park; 
(5)  Such further information as may be requested by the city manager to enable a determination of whether the proposed site will comply with the legal requirements. If the applicant is found to be of good moral character, the proposed manufactured home park is in compliance with all provisions of this article and all other applicable ordinances and statutes after the expiration of ten (10) days, the city council shall approve the application and on completion of the park according to the plans shall issue the license. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-19. - Annual license fee. 
The annual license fee for each manufactured home park shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for the first mobile home space and two dollars ($2.00) for each additional manufactured home space. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-20. - Posting of license. 
The license shall be conspicuously posted in the office of or on the premises of the manufactured home park at all times. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-21. - Revocation of license. 
The city council may, after a hearing, revoke any license to maintain and operate a park when the licensee has violated any provision of this article. After such revocation, the license may be reissued by the city council if the circumstances causing such violation have been remedied or corrected. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-22. - Occupancy. 
No manufactured home shall be occupied by a greater number of persons than that for which it is designed. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Secs. 12-23—12-33. - Reserved.  
Sec. 12-34. - Animals. 
No owner or person in charge of any dog, cat or other animal shall permit it to run at large or commit any nuisance within the limits of the manufactured home park. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-35. - Register of occupants. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the licensee to keep a register containing a record of all manufactured home owners and occupants located within the park. The register shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of each occupant; 
(2)  The make, model and year of all manufactured homes; 
(3)  The date of arrival and of departures of each manufactured home. 
(b)  The park shall keep the register available for inspection, at all times by law enforcement officers, public health officials and other officials whose duties necessitate acquisition of the information contained in the register. The register records shall not be destroyed for a period of three (3) years following the date of registration. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-36. - Supervision. 
A responsible attendant or caretaker, owner or operator shall be in charge at all times to keep the manufactured home park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition and the attendant or caretaker and the licensee shall be answerable for any violation of the provision of this article. Such attendant or caretaker, owner or operator shall be available at any reasonable time to assist the law enforcement officers of the city in conducting an inspection of the park. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Sec. 12-37. - Alterations and additions - manufactured homes in manufactured home parks. 
No permanent additions of any kind shall be built onto or become a part of any manufactured homes in any manufactured home park. Skirting of manufactured homes is permissible, but such skirting shall not attach to the manufactured home permanently to the ground, provide a harborage for rodents or create a fire hazard. The wheels of the manufactured home may be removed and jacks or stabilizers may be placed under the frame of the manufactured home to prevent movement on the springs while the manufactured home is parked and occupied. This section is not applicable to manufactured homes in manufactured home subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 12-2018 , §§ 2—6, 5-2-18)  
Chapter 13 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Municipal court, art. VI. 
Cross reference— Duties of the city attorney and municipal judge, § 2-36; miscellaneous offenses, Ch. 11; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference— Municipal courts, C.R.S. 13-10-101 et seq.; trial by jury, C.R.S. 13-10-114(2), Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure, Rule 223. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 13-1—13-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-2001, §§ 9—11, adopted December 19, 2001, repealed former §§ 13-1—13-3 in their entirety, which pertained to municipal judge qualifications, appointment, term; salary and determination of such by ordinance; and authority to name person to serve as substitute; appointment by council on failure of judge to act; determination of compensation. These provisions derived from the 1964 Code, §§ 15-4, 15-6 and 15-7.  
Sec. 13-4. - Clerk of court. 
The city council may appoint a clerk of the municipal court whenever it deems the volume of business done by the court sufficient to justify such appointment. 
(Code 1964, § 15-25)  
Sec. 13-5. - Duty of judge and clerk to keep court register; clerk authority concerning traffic violations. 
The duties of the judge, and any court clerk, shall be to keep a register of the actions in the court including all fees and monies collected and an index thereof; to pay over to the director of finance of the city all fines, penalties and fees received monthly, all to be credited to the general fund; and to prepare and keep a docket for the court in which the judgments in each case shall be noted. The court clerk shall keep reports on an at least monthly basis covering all monies collected by the court, and such report shall state the number of cases filed in the court, how the same were disposed of, and such other matters of information concerning operation of the court as the judge may deem proper or the council may require. The court clerk shall have authority to resolve uncontested traffic violations in accordance with the fine schedule established by ordinance. Such resolved traffic violations shall be included in the reports referenced above. The court clerk shall have such further powers and duties as may be provided by ordinance or by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1964, § 15-26; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § H1, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 13-6. - Jurisdiction of court; powers and authority of judge. 
The municipal court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine all cases arising under the ordinances or Charter of the City of Alamosa, including those having juveniles as a named party. The municipal judge shall have all judicial powers provided by law relating to the operation of his/her court including, but not limited to, imposition of fines and penalties, enforcement of the court's orders and judgments, punishment of contempt, and the power to compel the attendance of witnesses. Unless superseded by Charter or ordinance the operation of the municipal court, and the conduct of the municipal judge, shall be governed by Colorado law and the rules of the Colorado Supreme Court. 
(Code 1964, § 15-8; Ord. No. 02-2001, §§ 1, 2, 2-21-01; Ord. No. 11-2001, § 12, 12-19-01)  
Sec. 13-7. - Sessions of court. 
There shall be regular sessions of court for the trial of cases, and the municipal judge shall hear and determine complaints for the violation of any city ordinance or Charter where there is probably cause to believe that an offense has been committed, provided that it shall be lawful for the municipal judge to hold a special session of court at any time if in the discretion of the judge of the municipal court a special session is deemed advisable. In so far as it is practicable, traffic cases shall be heard separately from other cases. 
(Code 1964, § 15-18)  
Sec. 13-8. - Municipal court of record established. 
The municipal court in and for the city, organized to hear and try all alleged violations of ordinance provisions of the city, is hereby established as a qualified municipal court of record pursuant to provisions of C.R.S. 13-10-101 et seq. The court shall operate in conformity with the Charter and ordinances of the city, shall keep a verbatim record of the proceedings and evidence of trials by either electronic devices or stenographic means, and the judge of the court shall have been admitted to and currently be licensed in the practice of law in the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. No. 8-1996, § 1, 6-5-96; Ord. No. 11-1998, § 1, 6-3-98) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 8-1996, § 1, adopted June 5, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as § 13-8 herein was at the discretion of the editor.  
Sec. 13-9. - Jurisdiction of court; civil restraining orders. 
The municipal court is authorized to issue temporary and permanent civil restraining orders, pursuant to section 13-14-102(1)(a), C.R.S., as amended. 
A person failing to comply with any order of the court issued pursuant to this section may be found in contempt of court or prosecuted for a violation of a civil restraining order pursuant to section 11-26 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 15-2000, § 1, 12-6-00)  
Secs. 13-10—13-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TRIAL BY JURY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Trial by jury, C.R.S. 13-10-114, 13-71-101 et seq., Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure, Rules 223, 224. 
 
Sec. 13-21. - Jury selection; municipal court procedures. 
(a)  The clerk of the municipal court shall be the jury commissioner for such court, and any deputy clerk of the municipal court shall be a deputy jury commissioner for such court. 
(b)  The jury commissioner shall keep and maintain a master jury list which may be the same as the state judicial department master jury list. If such state master list is not used, the master list shall be compiled and maintained by the city jury commissioner in the manner set forth in C.R.S. 13-71-107, as amended. Such master list shall be open to the public for examination as a public record. 
(c)  The jury commissioner shall maintain a master jury box into which the commissioner shall place the names or identifying numbers of prospective jurors taken from the master list. The number of jurors to be taken from the master list shall be determined by the judge of the municipal court and the jury commissioner. The names or identifying numbers of prospective jurors to be placed in the master jury box shall be selected by the jury commissioner at random from the master list in the following manner: The total number of names on the master list shall be divided by the number of names to be placed in the master jury box, and the whole number next greater than the quotient shall be the "key number." A "starting number" for making the selection shall then be determined by a random method from the numbers from one (1) to the key number, both inclusive. The required number of the names shall then be selected from the master list by picking in order the first name on the master list corresponding to the starting number and then successively the names appearing in the master list at intervals equal to the key number, recommencing if necessary at the start of the list until the required number of names has been selected. Upon recommencing at the start of the list, or if additional names are subsequently to be selected for the master jury box, names previously selected from the master list shall be disregarded in selecting the additional names. The jury commission may use an electronic or mechanical system or device in carrying out its duties under this subsection. 
(d)  The names of any prospective jurors who are determined by the jury commissioner to be nonresidents of the city shall be forthwith deleted and eliminated from such master jury box. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28(1)—(4); Ord. No. 11-2001, § 13, 12-19-01)  
Sec. 13-22. - Prospective jurors. 
(a)  From time to time and in a manner prescribed by the court, the jury commissioner shall publicly draw at random from the master jury box the names or identifying numbers of as many prospective jurors as the court by order may require. The clerk shall prepare an alphabetical list of the names drawn. Neither the names drawn nor the list shall be disclosed to any person other than pursuant to this article or specific order of the court. 
(b)  The court clerk shall mail to every prospective juror whose name is drawn from the master jury box a juror qualification form accompanied by instructions to fill and return the form by mail to the clerk within ten (10) days after its receipt. The juror qualification form is subject to approval by the court as to matters of form and shall elicit the name, address of residence, and age of the prospective juror, and whether the prospective juror is a citizen of the United States and a resident of the city, is able to read, speak, and understand the English language, has any physical or mental disability impairing his or her capacity to render satisfactory jury service, and whether the prospective juror does not have the right to vote by reason of a criminal conviction. The juror qualification form shall contain the prospective juror's declaration that his or her responses are true to the best of his or her knowledge, and the prospective juror's acknowledgement that a willful misrepresentation of a material fact may be punished by a fine or by imprisonment, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Notarization of the juror qualification form shall not be required. 
(c)  If the prospective juror is unable to fill out the form, another person may do it for the prospective juror, and shall indicate that he or she has done so and the reason therefor. If it appears there is an omission, ambiguity or error in a returned form, the court clerk shall again send the form with instructions to the prospective juror to make the necessary addition, clarification, or correction and to return the form to the jury commissioner within ten (10) days after its second receipt. 
(d)  Any prospective juror who fails to return a completed juror qualification form as instructed shall be directed by the jury commissioner to appear forthwith before the court clerk to fill out a juror qualification form. At the time of his or her appearance for jury service, or at the time of any interview before the court or clerk, any prospective juror may be required to fill out another juror qualification form in the presence of the court or clerk, at which time the prospective juror may be questioned, but only with regard to his or her responses to questions contained on the form and grounds for the prospective juror's excuse or disqualification. Any information thus acquired by the court or clerk shall be noted on the juror qualification form. 
(e)  A prospective juror who fails to appear as directed by the jury commissioner pursuant to subsection (d) above shall be ordered by the court to appear and show cause for such prospective juror's failure to appear as directed. If the prospective juror fails to appear pursuant to the court's order or fails to show good cause for his or her failure to appear as directed by the jury commissioner, such prospective juror is guilty of criminal contempt and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine or by imprisonment, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(f)  Any person who willfully misrepresents a material fact on a juror qualification form for the purpose of avoiding or securing service as a juror is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine or by imprisonment, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28; Ord. No. 11-2001, § 14, 12-19-01; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § H2, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 13-23. - Determination of qualifications. 
(a)  The court, upon request of the jury commissioner or a prospective juror or on its own initiative, shall determine on the basis of information provided on the juror qualification form or interview with the prospective juror or other competent evidence whether or not the prospective juror is disqualified for jury service. The court clerk shall enter this determination in the space provided on the juror qualification form and on the alphabetical list of names drawn from the master jury box. 
(b)  A prospective juror is disqualified to serve on a jury if the prospective juror: 
(1)  Is not a citizen of the United States, eighteen (18) years old, and a resident of the city; 
(2)  Is unable to read, speak, and understand the English language; 
(3)  Is incapable, by reason of his or her physical or mental disability, of rendering satisfactory jury service, but a person claiming this disqualification may be required to submit a physician's or authorized Christian science practitioner's certificate as to the disability, and the certifying physician or practitioner is subject to inquiry by the court at its discretion; however, no person shall be deemed to be incapable of jury service solely because of impaired vision or hearing in any degree, although the existence of a defect in the visual or auditory functions may be grounds for challenge for cause if the court is satisfied that the challenged person is incapable of performing the duties of a juror in a particular action without prejudice to the substantial rights of the challenging party; 
(4)  Does not have the right to vote by reasons of a criminal conviction; 
(5)  Is then a member of a district court or county court jury panel. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28(6); Ord. No. 27-2018 , § H3, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 13-24. - Selection of qualified jurors. 
(a)  The jury commissioner shall maintain a qualified jury box and shall place therein the names or identifying numbers of all prospective jurors drawn from the master jury box who are not disqualified. 
(b)  Any judge of the municipal court may by order direct the jury commissioner to draw and assign to the court the number of qualified jurors the commissioner deems necessary for the municipal jury panel. Upon receipt of the order and in a manner prescribed by the court, the jury commissioner shall publicly draw at random from the qualified jury box the number of qualified jurors specified. The court clerk thereafter shall cause each person drawn for jury service to be served with a summons either personally or by mail addressed to such person at his or her usual residence, business, or post office address, requiring such person to report for jury service at a specified time and place. 
(c)  Where there is an unanticipated shortage of available jurors drawn from the qualified jury box, the court may require a police officer or the jury commissioner to summon a sufficient number of jurors from bystanders, but either party may show cause why bystanders should not be used, in which case additional jurors may be selected at random by the court clerk from the qualified jury box or in any other manner prescribed by the court. 
(d)  The names of qualified jurors drawn from the qualified jury box shall be made available to the public and the content of the juror qualification forms completed by the jurors shall be made available to parties or their attorneys unless the court determines in any instance in the interest of justice that this information be kept confidential or its use limited in whole or in part. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28(7); Ord. No. 27-2018 , § H4, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 13-25. - Exemption. 
No qualified prospective juror is exempt from jury service. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28(8))  
Sec. 13-26. - Jurors excused from service. 
(a)  The court, or any officer thereof designated by the court, upon request of a prospective juror or on its own initiative, shall determine on the basis of information provided on the juror qualification form or interview with the prospective juror or other competent evidence whether or not the prospective juror should be excused from jury service. The court clerk shall enter this determination in the space provided on the juror qualification form. 
(b)  A person who is not disqualified for jury service may be excused from jury service by the court only upon a showing of undue hardship, extreme inconvenience, or public necessity for a period the court deems necessary, at the conclusion of which the person shall reappear for jury service in accordance with the court's direction. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28(9))  
Sec. 13-27. - Length of service by jurors. 
In any three-year period, a person shall not be required to serve or attend court for prospective service as a petit juror more than ten (10) court days except when necessary to complete service in a particular case.  
Sec. 13-28. - Penalties for failure to perform jury service. 
A person summoned for jury service who fails to appear or to complete jury service as directed may be served with a summons, by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, requiring such person to appear or to complete jury service as directed. Should such person not appear in response thereto, he or she may be ordered by the court to appear forthwith and show cause for his or her failure to comply with the summons. If such person fails to show good cause for noncompliance with the summons, he or she is guilty of contempt and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine or by imprisonment, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28(11); Ord. No. 11-2001, § 15, 12-19-01; Ord. No. 1-2018 , § 8, 2-7-18; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § H5, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 13-29. - Court rules. 
The municipal court may make and amend rules, not inconsistent with this article, regulating the selection and service of jurors. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28(12))  
Sec. 13-30. - Juror's fees. 
Every person selected to serve on a jury shall be entitled to a per-diem payment in the amount of six dollars ($6.00) per calendar day of actual service during a trial or any part thereof. In the event a person is convicted of any offense by a jury, such fees shall be assessed by the court as costs against such convicted person, as otherwise provided in this Article. 
(Ord. No. 1-1990, § 3, 4-4-90)  
Secs. 13-31—13-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - RIGHTS OF ACCUSED

All cases in the municipal court shall be open to the public, provided, however, that where the type of offense charged and the nature of the case are such that it would be to the best interests of the witnesses and/or defendant or defendants to exclude all persons not directly connected with the case, the municipal judge may order that the court be cleared of all persons not so directly connected with the case. This decision shall be solely in the discretion of the municipal judge. 
(Code 1964, § 15-19)  
Sec. 13-51. - Same—Oral or written explanation of defendants' rights required. 
At the beginning of each court session, the municipal judge shall explain generally to defendants their rights in municipal court, as well as the general order of trial, provided, however, that this may be done by pamphlet distributed to each defendant. 
(Code 1964, § 15-20)

Sec. 13-53. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-2001, § 20, adopted December 19, 2001, repealed in its entirety former § 13-53, which pertained to continuances and derived from the Code of 1964, § 15-22.  
Sec. 13-54. - Failure to pay fine, penalties or costs; authority of judge to suspend fine, grant stay of execution, grant deferred sentences or deferred prosecution. 
Every person against whom any fine, penalty or costs shall be assessed under the ordinances of the city and who shall refuse or neglect forthwith to pay the same on such conviction or upon assessing of such fine, costs or penalty, and where the court record reflects that the defendant has willfully failed to pay such fine, costs or penalty, the court, when appropriate, may, on its own motion or on motion filed by the prosecutor, impose part or all of a suspended sentence, may revoke probation, or may institute proceedings for contempt of court. If the court finds a defendant in contempt of court for willful failure to pay, there shall be no imprisonment in those cases when no imprisonment is provided for in the possible sentence and any term of imprisonment shall otherwise comport with the provisions of C.R.S. § 18-1.3-702 as that statute may be amended from time to time. 
The court shall not find the defendant in contempt of court, nor impose a suspended sentence, nor revoke probation, nor order the defendant to jail for failure to pay unless the court has made findings on the record, after providing notice to the defendant and a hearing, that the defendant has the ability to comply with the court's order to pay a monetary amount due without undue hardship to the defendant or the defendant's dependents and that the defendant has not made a good-faith effort to comply with the order. If the defendant fails to appear at the hearing referenced herein after receiving notice, the court may issue a warrant for his or her arrest for failure to appear. 
The court shall not accept a defendant's guilty plea for contempt of court for failure to pay or failure to comply with the court's order to pay a monetary amount unless the court has made findings on the record that the defendant has the ability to comply with the court's order to pay a monetary amount due without undue hardship to the defendant or the defendant's dependents and that the defendant has not made a good-faith effort to comply with the order. 
The court shall not issue a warrant for failure to pay money, failure to appear to pay money, or failure to appear at any post-sentencing court appearance wherein the defendant was required to appear if he or she failed to pay a monetary amount. The court may issue an arrest warrant or incarcerate a defendant related to his or her failure to pay a monetary amount only through the procedures described in C.R.S. § 18-1.3-702(3)(a) to (d) as that statute may be amended from time to time. 
The municipal judge shall have the power to suspend fines and penalties, but not costs, and to grant stays of execution as is now or may hereafter be provided by general law, but not for a period of time in excess of a reasonable time within which to pay such fines, penalties or costs. 
In addition to all other powers vested in the municipal court by Colorado state law and the Colorado Supreme Court, the municipal judge shall have the authority to grant deferred prosecutions and deferred judgments in all cases within the jurisdiction of the municipal court in those circumstances and upon such terms as the municipal judge deems appropriate. 
(Code 1964, § 15-23; Ord. No. 1-1990, § 2, 4-4-90; Ord. No. 5-1995, § 5, 3-1-95; Ord. No. 1-2018 , § 9, 2-7-18) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1-2018 , § 9, adopted Feb. 7, 2018, repealed and reenacted § 13-54 to read as herein set out. Historical notation has been retained for reference purposes.  
Sec. 13-55. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-2001, § 21, adopted December 19, 2001, repealed in its entirety former § 13-55, which pertained to reduction of sentence and derived from the Code of 1964, § 15-24.  
Sec. 13-56. - Costs to be assessed upon conviction of municipal offenses. 
Every defendant who pleads guilty, nolo contendere, or who enters a plea agreement, or who after trial, is found guilty of a violation of the city Code, shall be assessed costs, including any law enforcement surcharges, by the court, which costs may not be abated or suspended, except for a reasonable time within which to pay the same. The costs to be assessed and the amounts thereof shall be set by resolution of the city council, and may be amended and adjusted from time to time by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 15-27; Ord. No. 1-1990, § 1, 4-4-90; Ord. No. 5-1995, § 7, 3-1-95; Ord. No. 7-1997, § 2, 5-7-97; Ord. No. 13-2016 , § 1, 7-6-16)  
Sec. 13-57. - Right to jury trial. 
(a)  Any defendant charged with a violation of this Code that constitutes a jailable offense shall have the right to demand a trial by jury upon compliance with the provisions of state law and the "Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure." 
(b)  No defendant shall have a right to a trial by jury for any non-criminal traffic infraction, nor for any violation that does not carry the possibility of the imposition of a sentence of incarceration (non-jailable offense). If the defendant is charged with any other jailable offense arising out of the same incident as forms the basis for a charge of a non-jailable offense, the defendant shall have the right to demand and, if such demand is in conformance with applicable law and the "Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure," to receive a trial by jury as to all such offenses, which shall be consolidated for purposes of trial. 
(Ord. No. 5-1995, § 3, 3-1-95; Ord. No. 1-2018 , § 10, 2-7-18)

A copy of the International Property Maintenance Code shall be maintained in the office of the Building Inspector of the City of Alamosa, and may be inspected during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 18, 2010, § 1, 12-1-10; Ord. No. 24-2018 , § 3, 9-5-18)
