Sec. 19-21. - Adoption of Model Traffic Code. 
Pursuant to parts 1 and 2 of article 16 of title 31 and part 4 of article 15 of title 30, C.R.S., there is hereby adopted by reference Articles I and II, inclusive, of the 2010 edition of the "Model Traffic Code" promulgated and published as such by the Colorado Department of Transportation, Safety and Traffic Engineering Branch, 4201 East Arkansas Avenue, EP 700., Denver, CO 80222. The subject matter of the Model Traffic Code relates primarily to comprehensive traffic control regulations for the city. The purpose of this article and the Code adopted herein is to provide a system of traffic regulations consistent with state law and generally conforming to similar regulations throughout the state and the nation. Three (3) copies of the Model Traffic Code adopted herein are now filed in the office of the Clerk of the City of Alamosa, Colorado, and may be inspected during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 07-2003, § 1, 7-2-03; Ord. No. 9-2009, § 1, 9-2-09; Ord. No. 5-2010, § 1, 6-2-10)  
Sec. 19-22. - Deletions. 
The 2010 edition of the Model Traffic Code is adopted as if set out at length save and except the following articles and/or sections which are declared to be inapplicable to the city and are therefore expressly deleted: Section 1409(9). 
(Ord. No. 07-2003, § 2, 7-2-03; Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 9-2-09; Ord. No. 5-2010, § 2, 6-2-10)  
Sec. 19-23. - Additions or modifications. 
The 2010 edition of the Model Traffic Code is subject to the following additions or modifications: 
(1)  Section 225(3) of the Model Traffic Code is hereby to read in its entirety as follows: 
(3) Any person who violates subsection (1) of this section commits a class B traffic infraction. Any person who violates subsection (1.5) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars. 
(2)  Section 1204(6) of the Model Traffic Code is hereby amended to read in its entirety as follows: 
(6) On any street or at any place within this municipality where an official sign is posted giving notice of stopping, standing or parking restrictions or prohibitions, no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle in any manner in violation of the provisions contained on such sign or signs, except where necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, or except for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers when such standing does not obstruct, impede, or endanger any traffic. 
(3)  Section 1205 of the Model Traffic Code is hereby amended by the addition of the following subsection (4) and the renumbering of the existing subsection (4) to be subsection (5), to wit: 
(4) On the streets which have been approved and signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings within a marked parking space and with the right front wheel of the vehicle against the curb or within six (6) inches thereof. No vehicle shall be parked in any angled parking space having space markings in such a manner that the vehicle extends beyond the length of the painted space markings or beyond length limitations as indicated on appropriate signs. 
(5) Any person who violates any provision of this section commits a class B traffic infraction. 
(4)  Section 1208(1)(b) of the Model Traffic Code is hereby amended to read in its entirety as follows: 
(1) (b) As used in this section, "person with a disability" has the meaning provided for such term in C.R.S. section 42-3-204(1) and includes any person who has qualified for and obtained disabled veteran special license plates with the identifying feature for a person with a physical impairment affecting mobility under C.R.S. section 42-3-213(5)(a)(II). 
(5)  Section 1412(10) of the Model Traffic Code is hereby amended by the following addition: 
(d) No bicycles in central business area. No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within the central business area of the City of Alamosa, which area, for the purposes of this section, shall comprise the sidewalks adjacent to the following streets: Those parts of Ross, Edison, San Juan, State, Hunt and Denver Avenues lying between the north sidewalk adjacent to Fourth Street and the south sidewalk adjacent to Sixth Street; and those parts of Fourth, Main and Sixth Streets lying between the west sidewalk adjacent to Ross Avenue and the east sidewalk adjacent to Denver Avenue. 
(e) No adults riding bicycles on sidewalks along certain streets. No person over the age of 16 shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk adjacent to State Street between Seventeenth Street and First Street; adjacent to Fourth, Main, or Sixth Street between Ross Avenue and West Avenue, or adjacent to First Street between Cole Park and Victoria Street unless accompanying and within 30 feet of a child under the age of 17. 
(Ord. No. 07-2003, § 3, 7-2-03; Ord. No. 02-2006, § 1, 5-5-06; Ord. No. 9-2007, § 1, 6-20-07; Ord. No. 9-2009, § 3, 9-2-09; Ord. No. 5-2010, § 3, 6-2-10; Ord. No. 22-2018 , §§ 1, 2, 8-1-18)  
Sec. 19-24. - Application. 
This article shall apply to every street, alley, sidewalk area, driveway, park and to every other public way or public place or public parking area, either within or outside the corporate limits of the city, the use of which the city has jurisdiction and authority to regulate. The provisions of sections 1401, 1402, and 1413 of the adopted Model Traffic Code, respectively concerning reckless driving, careless driving, eluding a police officer, and accidents and accident reports shall apply not only to public places and ways but also throughout the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-2003, § 5, 7-2-03; Ord. No. 5-2010, § 4, 6-2-10)  
Sec. 19-25. - Interpretation. 
This article shall be so interpreted and construed as to effectuate its general purpose to conform with the state's uniform system for the regulation of vehicles and traffic. Article and section headings of the article and adopted Model Traffic Code shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or extent of the provisions of any article or section thereof. 
(Ord. No. 07-2003, § 8, 7-2-03; Ord. No. 5-2010, § 7, 6-2-10)  
Secs. 19-26—19-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING 
 
Sec. 19-41. - Parking of certain vehicles, time limit on streets; extension into street. 
(a)  No person shall park, place, locate or keep any manufactured housing, motor home, mobile home, camper, trailer, recreational vehicle, or any other trailer designed to be pulled by a motor vehicle, upon any public street, alley, park or way of the city for a period of time exceeding seventy-two (72) hours; and no such trailer, trailer house or recreational vehicle shall be parked upon any such street of the city so as to extend outward into the street a distance in excess of ten (10) feet measured at right angles to the curb. The restrictions delineated in this subsection (a) are subject to such additional regulations in subsections (b) of this section 19-41. 
(b)  No person shall park, place, locate or keep any truck tractor drawing a semitrailer, upon any public street, alley, park or way of the city in residentially zoned areas of the city, provided that such truck tractors may make necessary stops not exceeding five (5) minutes in length, or emergency stops, and may make stops for the purpose of making deliveries. 
(c)  No person shall park a vehicle upon a street, alley, highway, or other public right-of-way for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing, painting or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(3)  Displaying advertising. 
(Code 1964, § 19-5; Ord. No. 2-1996, § 1, 1-17-96; Ord. No. 4-1998, § 1, 4-1-98)  
Sec. 19-42. - Vehicles hauling flammable merchandise; where parking permitted. 
No truck hauling flammable merchandise on any street in the city shall be parked on any street of this city except within the central business district or along any state highway, provided that such trucks may make necessary temporary stops not exceeding five (5) minutes in length, or emergency stops, and may make stops for the purpose of making deliveries, at other points within the city limits. 
(Code 1964, § 19-12)  
Sec. 19-43. - Additional parking restrictions. 
(a)  All night parking prohibited; limitations. Except for licensed or certified medical care providers or any other person(s) responding to an emergency call, no person shall park a vehicle for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes during the period of time between two o'clock a.m., and five o'clock a.m. (2:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m.), of any day on a street segment which is signed to prohibit all-night parking. 
(b)  Parking in alleys prohibited; limitations. 
(1)  No person shall park a vehicle within an alley, except during the necessary and expeditious loading and unloading of merchandise or freight, and except for licensed or certified medical care providers or any other person(s) acting in a similar role in responding to an emergency call. 
(2)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within any public or private street, highway, or alley in such position as to block the driveway, garage, or alley entrance to any property abutting such public street, highway, or alley. 
(c)  Presumption established; municipal court hearings. In any prosecution charging a violation of any parking regulation or provision for stopping, standing, or parking of a vehicle, encompassed by the Code of Ordinances of the City of Alamosa, including codes adopted by reference, proof that the vehicle alleged in the offense to be the vehicle in violation of such a provision was such vehicle, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such alleged violation the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 03-2006, § 1, 7-5-06)  
Secs. 19-44—19-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - RAILROADS 
 
Sec. 19-61. - Blocking streets. 
All railroad companies shall make up their trains on grounds owned by them, and any agent or employee of any railroad company in charge of any engine, car or train of cars shall not suffer or permit any engine, car or train of cars to stand upon or cross any street of the city at the intersection of any street with such railroad during a period of time longer than ten (10) minutes. 
(Code 1964, § 17-53)  
Chapter 20 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - WASTEWATER SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 20-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to generate sufficient revenue to pay from the service charge for usage of the Alamosa wastewater system all costs of the operation and maintenance of the complete wastewater system. To the extent reasonably accomplishable, the costs shall be allocated to the users of the system in proportion to each user's contribution to the total loading of the treatment works and collection system. To insure a proportional distribution of the operation and maintenance costs to each user or user-class, a non-exclusive delineation of factors to be included as criteria for determining the usage charges are as follows: Strength, bio-chemical oxygen demand (BOD), total suspended solids (TSS), volume, and delivery flow-rate characteristics shall be considered and included in the bases for determining the users' respective charges. The other provisions in this article shall be construed consistently with this stated purpose. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95)  
Sec. 20-2. - Determining the total annual cost of operation and maintenance. 
The city engineer or designee shall determine the total annual cost of the operation of the wastewater treatment system and the total annual costs of maintaining said system. Such determinations shall include not only the variable operating costs, but also the costs reasonably projected to maintain the capacity and performance of the system during its expected service life, consistently with its initial design and construction. The total annual costs of operation and maintenance shall include, but shall not be limited to, labor, repairs, equipment replacement (including sinking funds), routine upkeep, maintenance, necessary modifications to the system, power, sampling, laboratory tests, and a reasonable contingency fund. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95)  
Sec. 20-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 20-2016 , § 1, adopted December 7, 2016, repealed § 20-3, which pertained to determining each user's wastewater contribution percentage and derived from Ord. No. 8-1995, adopted May 3, 1995.  
Sec. 20-4. - Determining a surcharge for users with excess BOD and TSS. 
The city shall assess a surcharge for all non-residential users discharging wastes with bio-chemical oxygen demand (BOD) and total suspended solids (TSS) strengths greater than those of the typical residential user. For purposes of this section, normal strength wastes are considered to be two hundred (200) milligrams per liter BOD and one hundred forty (140) milligrams per liter TSS. An atypical, non-residential user's BOD and TSS strengths shall be determined by laboratory analysis of the user's discharge performed by the city at such intervals and times as the city deems appropriate. The surcharge rate structure for such above-normal strength waste dischargers will be sufficient to cover the costs of treating such user's above normal strength wastes. Said users shall pay an additional surcharge as set forth below in section 20-5, for each twenty-five (25) milligrams per liter of BOD over the normal strength wastes as defined above, and for each ten (10) milligrams per liter of TSS over the normal strength wastes as defined above. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95; Ord. No. 20-2016 , § 2, 12-7-16)  
Sec. 20-5. - Determining each user's wastewater service charge. 
Each user's wastewater charge will be assessed by applying the applicable volumetric rate per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water, or fraction thereof, used plus a flat monthly rate, plus any applicable BOD or TSS surcharge as set forth below for the period of time from January 1, 2019 to December 31, 2023. In making such assessment, the city may classify industrial, commercial, and other non-residential establishments as a residential user, provided that the wastes for these establishments are equivalent to the wastes from the average residential user with respect to volume, BOD and TSS.

Each user's volumetric charge will be based on the average of their November, December, January, and February water use for the immediately preceding year unless adjusted by the city for exceptional circumstances. Any such adjustments will be reflected on the first full month's bill along with notification of the change. This will minimize the impact of irrigation on the calculation of volume used as the basis for the sewer use volumetric charges. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95; Ord. No. 12-1995, 3-15-95; Ord. No. 4-2009, § 1, 4-15-09; Ord. No. 20-2016 , § 3, 12-7-16; Ord. No. 30-2018 , § 1, 11-7-18)  
Sec. 20-6. - Wastewater facilities replacement fund. 
A reserve fund, the wastewater facilities replacement fund is hereby established within the wastewater utility fund for the purpose of providing sufficient funds for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, and appurtenances during the useful life of the wastewater treatment facilities so as to maintain the capacity and performance levels for which such facilities were designed and constructed. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95)  
Sec. 20-7. - Payment of the user's wastewater service charge and penalties. 
(a)  All water and sewer fees shall be charged against the property served and against the owner thereof, and if for any reason any sums owing therefor become delinquent, all provisions for collection of delinquent payments, hereunder may be pursued against the owners of the serviced property, notwithstanding that the occupant or actual user of such services may be other than the owner of the property. 
(b)  If any user of the sewer system shall neglect, fail or refuse to pay the rates and charges fixed by section 20-5 for use of the system, such user and the premises occupied by him or her shall not be disconnected from the system, but the charges due from any such person and delinquent upon October first of any year shall be certified by the city clerk to the county within ten (10) days after such date, together with a statement showing the names of the delinquent users and the description of the real property served by sewer connection for which charges fixed by section 20-5 are delinquent. Such charges shall thereupon become a lien upon such real property and may be collected in the manner provided by state statute. Charges imposed upon real property which are not subject to taxation or lien under the constitution or laws of this state by reason of its ownership, character, or use, may be collected by any appropriate action in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95)  
Sec. 20-8. - Review of each user's wastewater service charge. 
If a significant user, such as an industry, has completed in-plant modifications which would change that user's wastewater contribution percentage, the user can present to the city's public works director such factual information and the public works director shall then determine if the user's wastewater contribution percentage is to be changed. The city shall notify the user of its findings as soon as possible. The user may appeal the director's decision pursuant to the provisions of section 20-58. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95; Ord. No. 4-2009, § 1, 4-15-09; Ord. No. 20-2016 , § 4, 12-7-16)  
Sec. 20-9. - Wastes prohibited from discharge to the wastewater treatment system. 
(a)  The discharge of any substance containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly, or by interaction with other wastes, to contaminate the sludge of municipal systems, or to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in or have an adverse effect on the waters receiving any discharge from the treatment works is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Each user which discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of managing the effluent or the sludge of the city wastewater treatment works shall be obligated for such increased costs, and shall be subject to penalties for violation of this section as provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 5-3-95)  
Sec. 20-10. - Sewer service connection fees. 
(a)  As an expense of connection to a sewer service line, a sewer service connection fee shall be paid, subject to the exceptions delineated below, which sewer service connection fee shall be the aggregate of the tapping fee and plant investment fee delineated below: 
Size of Connection 
(in inches) 	Tapping Fee* 	Plant Investment Fee 
 4 	$ 500.00 	$ 500.00 
 6 	750.00 	1,250.00 
 8 	1,000.00 	3,000.00 
10 	1,500.00 	4,500.00 
12 	2,000.00 	7,000.00

(b)  The property owner shall pay the city's cost for running the service line to the city line. Other than the connection fee, as specified above, for one (1) unit, no connection fee shall be charged for structures or complexes of structures which contain more than one (1) dwelling or commercial unit and which are served by a single connection; each connection in excess of one (1) connection, however, shall require payment of the full applicable fee designated above, regardless of the number of structures, complexes of structures, dwellings or commercial units. 
(c)  If the sewer service has been installed and paid by a party approved in advance by the city, the tapping fee shall not apply. Upon the installation of a replacement line where a service connection fee has been previously paid, the plant investment fee shall not apply, and the tapping fee shall be limited to the actual cost of labor, equipment, and materials, as determined by the city, to install the service line. The sewer connection fees delineated above may be altered by agreement between the city and the tap recipient in accordance with terms, conditions, and upon the standards set by the city council, from time to time, by resolution.  
Secs. 20-11—20-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER 
 
Sec. 20-16. - Name of system. 
(a)  The waterworks constructed by the city and used to supply the city and its inhabitants with water, shall be known as the "Alamosa Waterworks." 
(b)  Such waterworks and all things pertaining thereto shall be under the control of the city council, who shall direct the maintenance and operation thereof, and the construction of all additions thereto, and in all cases not particularly provided for by ordinance, shall determine in what manner and upon what terms water may be taken from the water system by any water consumer and the character of the connections and appliances which may be made or used therefor. 
(Code 1964, § 20-1)  
Sec. 20-17. - Water system property; injury, tampering, trespass. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or in anywise damage any property or appliances constituting or being a part of such waterworks, or any fences, guards, rails, boxes, covers, buildings, or water tower constructed and used to protect the waterworks or any part thereof. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person except the superintendent of water, or those employed by the superintendent or authorized by the city council, to operate the waterworks to trespass upon the waterworks or the grounds upon which the same are constructed, to tap or make connection therewith or in any manner to interfere with the waterworks or the property or the appliances constituting the waterworks or any part thereof, or to meddle or interfere with any pipe, valve or appliances used regulating the flow of water in the waterworks, or any part thereof, or to change or alter the position of any valve or appliance regulating the flow of water in any pipe line of the waterworks. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere or meddle with or attempt to alter or change the flow of any well or wells which are a part of the waterworks or in any way connected therewith. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cast, place, dump or deposit in any pipe, reservoir, well, filter, or any part whatsoever of the waterworks, any substance or material which will in any manner injure or obstruct the same or any material or substance which will contaminate or pollute or which would tend to contaminate or pollute the water in the waterworks or in any pipe, reservoir, filter, sedimentation basin, well, or any appliance forming a part of the waterworks, or in any manner to obstruct the waterworks or pollute the water therein. 
(Code 1964, § 20-2; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § K1, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 20-18. - Fire hydrants. 
(a)  All fire hydrants shall be under the control and shall be kept in repair by the superintendent of water and shall be tested frequently to see if the same are in order. In case of fire the members of the fire department and such other persons as the superintendent of water shall authorize, shall have free access to the fire hydrants. No other person shall open or operate any fire hydrants without permission of the superintendent of water, or draw water therefrom, or destroy the approach thereto. 
(b)  Wrenches for fire hydrants shall be furnished by the superintendent to the fire department, whether the department be a voluntary or paid department, for the use of its members and to such other persons as the superintendent may deem proper, and no person to whom any wrench is so furnished shall permit the same to be taken from the place of deposit, or to be used by any other person for any other purpose than that authorized by the superintendent. 
(Code 1964, § 20-3)  
Sec. 20-19. - Only superintendent of waterworks and licensed plumbers authorized to tap or make pipeline connections; provisions for permit applications by consumers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than the superintendent of the water department or a plumber holding a current license issued by the city to tap or make any connection with any pipeline or water main forming a part of the city waterworks. 
(b)  Any person desiring to have a tap made to the pipes or mains of the city water system or any connection therewith to use water therefrom, shall make application in writing for a permit to do so to the public works director, agreeing to pay such rates for the use of water as may be then or thereafter established by the city council, and also agreeing to conform to and to be governed by such rules and regulations that may from time to time be adopted by the city council for the government and control of the city waterworks system or any part thereof. Such application shall also state the nature or character of the tap or connection; the location by lot, block and street number thereof; the number of taps; the premises upon which the water is sought to be used; the character and size of the premises; and the nature and purpose for which the water is to be used. Every application shall be accompanied by the applicable plant investment fee. If the application is complete and the proposed tap and use conform to applicable rules and regulations, the city clerk shall issue a permit for such tap. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § K2, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 20-20. - Signing, records, copies. 
(a)  All permits shall be issued and signed by the public works director or the director's designee and shall set forth the name of the person for whose benefit they shall be granted, the date thereof, the point on the water main at which the tapping is to be done, the size and number of taps and stopcock, the premises to which the water is to be conducted, the use to be made of the water and the number and character of the appliances through which the same is to be used. 
(b)  The public works director shall keep a record of all permits issued in a book or books kept for such purpose, and shall cause to be made the connections therein provided. 
(Code 1964, § 20-5; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § K3, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 20-21. - Connection with service pipe from other premises prohibited. 
No connection with the waterworks or use of water therefrom shall be made through any extension of a service pipe serving any other premises. 
(Code 1964, § 20-7)  
Sec. 20-22. - Taps installed subsequent to permit issuance; specifications regulated by city; connected at consumer expense; become city property. 
(a)  Every tap inserted in or connected with the service pipes shall have an orifice of a diameter prescribed by the city; the service pipe shall be connected with such tap by copper pipe, and the service pipe shall extend from the main to the curbline, at which point shall be placed a stopcock with a cover, or if there be no curbline, then at such point as the superintendent of water shall direct, so that the same shall be accessible to the superintendent of water for the purpose of turning on or shutting off water by means thereof. 
(b)  Upon the issuance of a permit for a tap as provided in this article, it shall be the responsibility of the water consumer to have such tap made at his or her own expense. The city may install such taps and waterlines at the request of water consumers for such charges as the city council may from time to time establish by resolution. All such taps and waterlines shall meet the specifications set by the city, and all taps, service lines, stopcocks, and appliances from the water main to and including the stopcock shall become the property of the city. 
(c)  Every tap shall be of brass, all service pipes shall be of copper, and all materials and work shall meet with city specifications. 
(Code 1964, § 20-8; Ord. No. 10-1988, 10-5-88; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § K4, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 20-23. - Issuance of permit in violation of article provisions deemed unlawful; other violations enumerated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the public works director to issue any permit for any connection with the waterworks other than in the manner provided by this article; or for the superintendent of water to permit any tap or connection to be installed or made before a permit has been issued, or contrary to or in excess of the provisions of such permit. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by ordinance to make a connection with any water pipe or main of the waterworks, or for any person to put in any tap or connection contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any water consumer to use water through any tap, fire hydrant, or service connection with the water main contrary to the provisions of this chapter, or to turn on water to his or her premises after the water has been shut off. 
(Code 1964, § 20-10; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § K5, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 20-24. - Liability for payment of water assessments; penalties for delinquencies and other violations of chapter. 
(a)  The liability for payment of the water charges and assessments for the use of city water under this chapter is hereby made the joint and several obligation of the person(s) entitled to possession of the premises served by the water at the time of usage, and of the owner of the property served. 
(b)  If any person responsible for payment of the charges or assessments from the use of municipal water shall neglect, fail or refuse to pay for the use of said water and all of the charges therefor or shall otherwise violate any of the provisions of this chapter, such person and the property served may, at the direction of the finance director or city council, be deprived of the use of water from the Alamosa Waterworks until fines assessed by the municipal court and all costs, including costs of connection and disconnection, damages and all water rents and charges of every kind shall be paid and until such offense or offenses shall have ceased. 
(c)  The rates specified in section 20-31 shall be paid on a pro rata monthly basis and shall be due and payable on the first day of each month. If not paid during the month in which they become due, they shall become delinquent. Assessments delinquent upon October 1 of each year shall be certified by the finance director to the county within ten (10) days after such date, together with a statement showing the names of the owners delinquent and the description of the real property served for which assessments fixed by section 20-31 are delinquent. Such assessments shall thereupon become a lien upon such real property and shall be collected in the manner provided by state statute. Assessments imposed upon real property which is not subject to taxation or lien under the constitution or laws of the state by reason of its ownership, character or use, may be collected by any appropriate action in the County Court or District Court of Alamosa County. 
(d)  For purposes of the delinquency and enforcement provisions of this chapter, all locations to which city water is provided with respect to an owner ("owner-user") or with respect to a person entitled to possession of the premises served by city water at the time of usage ("possessor-user") shall be aggregated and thus treated as one water account of that owner-user and of that possessor-user. The default of an owner-user or of a possessor-user at one location shall be deemed a default at all locations for which the defaulting owner-user or defaulting possessor-user is liable for the usage charges. 
(Code 1964, § 20-11; Ord. No. 5-1992, §§ 1, 2, 8-5-92)  
Sec. 20-25. - Maintenance and repair of fixtures. 
(a)  The owner and user of any premises for which a connection is made and a stopcock with box and cover placed as aforesaid shall keep such stopcock with box and cover placed as aforesaid in good condition at such owner's or user's expense and so that the superintendent of water shall be able to turn and shut off water from the service pipes at any time. From the stopcock to, in and upon his or her premises the owner and user shall provide his or her own pipe and plumbing which shall be constructed and placed so as to comply with all ordinances governing plumbing and shall, at such owner's or user's expense, at all times keep all pipes, fixtures and appliances on his or her premises tight and in good working order, so as to prevent waste of water. 
(b)  In case any pipe or fixture shall break or become imperfect or so as to waste water, the owner or user shall forthwith repair the same and keep the same in repair. 
(c)  In case the superintendent of water shall ascertain that any plumbing or fixtures on any premises are so defective as to waste any water or are being used so as to waste any water, the superintendent shall notify the owner or user of water to forthwith repair the same or remedy the situation; and if the owner or user fails to repair the same, the superintendent may forthwith shut off the water from such premises, and the same shall remain shut off until such plumbing and fixtures are repaired or such situation remedied. 
(Code 1964, § 20-12; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § K6, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 20-26. - Application and establishment of account required for turning water on; administrative fees; optional deposit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any plumber or other persons to turn on or cause to be turned on water to any premises, whether improved or not, unless such water is turned on at the direction of the superintendent of water after application for use of water has been made to the finance director and after approval has been granted by the superintendent of water; provided, however, this provision shall not prohibit turning water temporarily off to allow for repairs and restoring service after repairs are completed. 
(b)  The application for turning on water shall include, but not be limited to, a statement by the applicant that the applicant has read and is familiar with and will abide by and accept all provisions in the City Code, whether then in effect or subsequently adopted, regarding utility services provided by the city as conditions precedent to the initiation and maintenance of utility service to the applicant from the city. Such an application will be required for all requests for new services, whether or not the applicant is a new owner, new occupant, the premises are new to city services, or the location for the intended service was previously served by the city water system. 
(c)  In the event the applicant has not previously had an account with the city, or in the event the applicant was delinquent in payment of any utilities account with the city three (3) or more times within the preceding thirty-six (36) months, the water superintendent may require a deposit not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), which deposit shall be returned to the water user, without interest, after the water user has paid timely for utility services for twelve (12) consecutive months or upon cessation of the utilities account, whichever occurs first. 
(d)  For turning on the delivery of water to any premises, except as provided in paragraph (a) above, or when the shutoff was for the purpose of the city making repairs or improvements to the city's water delivery system, the water superintendent shall not approve the commencement of such water service until a turn-on service charge has been paid to the finance director and all delinquent water assessment liens upon the real property to be served have been satisfied. At the time water service is requested, the city shall inform the requesting person when the request can be honored within the then-existing commitments of the water superintendent. In the event the service turn-on is during normal city office hours, such water shall not be turned on until a charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) has been paid to the finance director; in the event the turn-on of service is to be done after hours, upon the request of the requesting party, such turning on of service shall not occur until the requesting person has paid a turn-on service charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) to the finance director. 
(Code 1964, § 20-14; Ord. No. 1-1991, § 1, 2-6-91; Ord. No. 5-1992, § 3, 8-5-92)  
Sec. 20-27. - Use of unmetered water unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from the city water system on any premises if the flow of such water is not metered. If the superintendent of water determines that unmetered water from the city water system is being used on any premises, the superintendent shall shut off all water to the premises until proper meters have been installed. 
(Code 1964, § 20-16; Ord. No. 27-2018 , § K7, 10-3-18)  
Sec. 20-28. - Service charge for shutoff notice and a prerequisite to turn water on after service is continued. 
(a)  The superintendent of water, when required to serve a shutoff notice for the water for any cause other than making repairs or improvements to the premises or city's water delivery system, shall result in an administrative fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to be imposed and collected, in addition to any turn-on fees or costs, as part of, and in the same manner as, the water rates for usage, as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  The superintendent of water, after having caused the shutoff of water for nonpayment of charges, shall not allow the same to be turned on again until arrearages for usage fees have been paid, together with all costs, other charges, fines, penalties, and administrative fees specified in this article. 
(Code 1964, § 20-17; Ord. No. 1-1991, § 2, 2-6-91)  
Sec. 20-29. - Repairs to system, turning off water. 
The city council reserves the right to cause the water to be shut off from any street main when they deem if necessary for repairing the same or making connections or extensions of the same, or for the purpose of clearing the same, or for any necessary work in repairing the pipe line or other appliances or connections of the waterworks, and in case of repair on the pipe line or in case of scarcity or for any other reason may temporarily restrict the use of water, and if need be for any reason may forbid sprinkling and otherwise regulate the time, place and manner of use of water and purpose for which the same may be used, as occasion may require. In case of an emergency the mayor may, by proclamation, restrict or regulate the use of water until the next meeting of the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 20-18)  
Sec. 20-30. - Water service connection fees. 
(a)  As a condition precedent to connection to or use of the city water system, a water service connection fee shall be paid, subject to the exceptions delineated below in subsections (b), (c), (d), and (e), which service connection fee shall be the aggregate of the applicable tapping fee and plant investment fee delineated below: 
Size of Water Connection 
(in inches) 	Tapping Fee* 	Plant Investment Fee 
¾ 	$  500.00 	1,000.00 
1 	750.00 	1,700.00 
1½ 	1,000.00 	3,300.00 
2 	1,500.00 	5,300.00

(b)  The tapping fee for structures or complexes of structures which contain more than one (1) dwelling unit or commercial unit and which is to be serviced by more than one (1) meter shall be the fee for the appropriate tap size, plus the actual costs, as determined by the city, for time and materials for the installation of all meters in excess of the first meter. 
(c)  The service connection fee for fire protection service shall be limited to the actual cost of installation of the service line from the main to the property line. No meter shall be required for fire protection water usage. 
(d)  (1) If the water service has been installed and paid for by an approved party other than the city, the tapping fee shall be waived. 
(2)  If an existing water service is being replaced on a property where a service connection fee has been previously paid, the plant investment fee shall be waived, and the tapping fee shall be limited to the actual costs, as determined by the city, for time and materials, to install the service line. 
(e)  The water service connection fees delineated above may be altered by agreement between the city and the tap recipient in accordance with terms, conditions, and upon the standards effectuated by the city council, from time to time, by resolution. 
(Code 1964, § 20-18.1; Ord. No. 11-1992, § 1, 11-4-92; Ord. No. 4-2007, § 1, 4-4-07)  
Sec. 20-31. - Water rates within city limits. 
(a)  All water use shall be measured by standard meters to be installed in all places where water is or may have to be used from the city water system. 
(b)  In determining the category of use as set forth below for each type of water user, the following definitions shall be applicable: 
(1)  Residential water: Use in a dwelling. For purposes of the volumetric charge to be applied to any residential use that involves more than a single unit (multi-family dwellings, mobile home parks, apartment complexes, etc.), the volumetric category into which the user falls shall be determined by dividing the total usage by the number of single family residence equivalents making up that total usage. 
(2)  Senior water: Upon application by the consumer and upon determination by the city of the consumer's eligibility, water service to a residence occupied by any consumer, either as owner or lessee thereof, who is 65 years of age or older. 
(3)  Commercial water: Use in a commercial facility, including residential type uses in commercial lodging establishments such as hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, RV parks, etc. 
(4)  Institutional water: Use by any governmental, institutional, or any private entity in a campus type setting that experiences large seasonal water demand due to irrigation or other use. 
(c)  The monthly charge for water shall be the combined total of a monthly base charge and a monthly volume charge, computed as follows: 
(1)  The monthly base charge for each premise to which water service is available during the month, regardless of whether or not any water is consumed, shall be as set forth below. 
(2)  The monthly volumetric charge for a consumer within the city limits per one thousand (1,000) gallons (or fraction thereof) shall be as set forth below for the period of time from January 1, 2019 to December 31, 2023: 
Residential Water
